awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Social and environmental influences on inflammation
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation research project investigates how social and environmental factors that create stress ‘get under the skin’ through the process of inflammation, to influence biological outcomes that impact well-being over the life course. Chronic inflammation can be a cause or sign of disease, and inflammatory responses are precursors of poor health outcomes and offer insights into understanding disease onset. This project contributes to a clearer understanding of the ways in which social and environmental factors serve as mechanisms that induce inflammation, linking stress to disease. By focusing analysis on variation in the biomarker C-reactive protein (CRP), a well validated biomarker of inflammation, in relationship to variation in indices of environmental and psychosocial stress, the results of this study can contribute to better identifying the underpinnings of the links between stress, inflammation, environmental drivers, and biological outcomes. This is a community-centered project which provides research training to participants and sets the foundation for future research in this emerging area. 

Epigenetic pathways act as channels between social factors and disease risk throughout life, and epigenetic modifications can impact inflammatory responses. In clinically oriented research, variation in outcomes related to human health is often grouped into census-level categories that may not be informative with respect to understanding human biological variation. Incorporating environmental information and evidence of potentially linked epigenetic modifications can offer a more nuanced understanding of variation across the full pathway of causation, from mechanism to outcome. This project aims to 1) understand how variation in social and other environmental factors relates to variation in CRP concentrations, both within and across populations, and 2) to understand how social and environmental factors influence methylation in areas of the genome related to stress physiology and stress response. Taken together, results generated from this project can advance understanding of the underlying mechanisms involved in the transduction of environmental and lived experience to biological outcomes and inform theoretical frameworks regarding the evolution and trade-offs involved in these mechanisms within and across human populations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The project aimed to investigate how life experience translates into physiological systems via stress, specifically focusing on how social and environmental factors influence biological and genetic changes in inflammatory or metabolic related biomarkers. Research activities included:

  • Collecting genetic samples from 160 participants in Lagos, Nigeria.
  • Conducting interviews and stress surveys to gather contextualizable data on stress experiences.
  • Performing assay and pyrosequencing analysis to measure the amount of biomarkers and methylation levels associated with stress experiences
  • Performing secondary data analysis to examine metabolic profiles that influence individuals' risk for poor health conditions, focusing on how stress impacts these metabolic profiles.

The study identified several genetic and stress related experiences that influence biological and genetic changes in inflammatory related biomarkers among the sampled population. Notable findings include:

  • Ethnic group affiliation had a large effect on C-reactive protein (CRP) variability, CRP measures inflammation in the body. Specifically ethnic groups that are not the major ethic group in the region were samples were collected.
  • Methylation at some regions of the IL-6 promoter were significant predictors of CRP variability.
  • Cortisol, a biomarkers of stress also significant predicted CRP variability.

For the secondary data analysis 

  • Metabolic profiles consisting of HgbA1c, cholesterol, and sex among the samples population made them more at risk for chronic inflammatory conditions.
  • Black women had lower scores than men on most biomarkers linked to poor health, which is different from what researchers usually observe. However, despite these lower scores, Black women still showed a higher overall risk of developing diseases. This pattern reflects how Black women often experience worse health outcomes than men, largely due to the combined effects of racial and gender discrimination.

 

The project had significant broader impacts, including:

 

  • Forming cross cultural community connections and establishing future collaborations with populations often underrepresented in genetic and health related research.
  • Training and involving members of underrepresented communities.
  • Contributing to the study of race and disease susceptibility among the study populations.

 

Results from this project were disseminated through multiple channels:

 

  • Presentation and pending presentations at national and reginal conferences, including the Human biological annual meeting
  • Publications and pending publications in journal such as American journal of human biology
  • Pending dissemination to the broader community tin which data was collected.
  • An infographic that will be used to share how life experiences through stress  can impact health, that will be given out to participants in future iterations of this project.

 


Last Modified: 03/31/2025
Modified by: Jada P Benn Torres

The project aimed to investigate how life experience translates into physiological systems via stress, specifically focusing on how social and environmental factors influence biological and genetic changes in inflammatory or metabolic related biomarkers. Research activities included:

Collecting genetic samples from 160 participants in Lagos, Nigeria.
Conducting interviews and stress surveys to gather contextualizable data on stress experiences.
Performing assay and pyrosequencing analysis to measure the amount of biomarkers and methylation levels associated with stress experiences
Performing secondary data analysis to examine metabolic profiles that influence individuals' risk for poor health conditions, focusing on how stress impacts these metabolic profiles.



The study identified several genetic and stress related experiences that influence biological and genetic changes in inflammatory related biomarkers among the sampled population. Notable findings include:

Ethnic group affiliation had a large effect on C-reactive protein (CRP) variability, CRP measures inflammation in the body. Specifically ethnic groups that are not the major ethic group in the region were samples were collected.
Methylation at some regions of the IL-6 promoter were significant predictors of CRP variability.
Cortisol, a biomarkers of stress also significant predicted CRP variability.

Metabolic profiles consisting of HgbA1c, cholesterol, and sex among the samples population made them more at risk for chronic inflammatory conditions.
Black women had lower scores than men on most biomarkers linked to poor health, which is different from what researchers usually observe. However, despite these lower scores, Black women still showed a higher overall risk of developing diseases. This pattern reflects how Black women often experience worse health outcomes than men, largely due to the combined effects of racial and gender discrimination.






The project had significant broader impacts, including:




Forming cross cultural community connections and establishing future collaborations with populations often underrepresented in genetic and health related research.
